metadata.disclaimer: Based on publicly available crosswalks and expert analysis. Validate with qualified assessors for compliance/audit use.

clauses.title: The organizational mission is understood and informs cybersecurity risk management
clauses.rationale: PM-7 enterprise architecture; PM-8 critical infrastructure; PM-11 mission/business process definition. Mission context well addressed.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes organizational context beyond pure security mission alignment.

clauses.title: Internal and external stakeholders are understood, and their needs and expectations regarding cybersecurity risk management are understood and considered
clauses.rationale: PM-8 critical infrastructure planning includes stakeholders; PM-11 mission process definition; PM-15 security contacts.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 requires systematic stakeholder identification and expectation analysis. SP 800-53 partially addresses through program-level controls.

clauses.title: Legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements regarding cybersecurity are understood and managed
clauses.rationale: PM-1 program plan addresses legal context; PL-4 rules of behavior; SA-4 contractual requirements.
clauses.gaps: SP 800-53 lacks a dedicated legal/regulatory requirements identification control. Federal compliance assumed in FISMA context.

clauses.title: Critical objectives, capabilities, and services that external stakeholders depend on are understood and communicated
clauses.rationale: PM-8 critical infrastructure; PM-11 mission processes; CP-2 contingency planning includes critical service identification.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 requires explicit identification of stakeholder-dependent services. SP 800-53 addresses through mission/business process controls but less explicitly.

clauses.title: Outcomes, capabilities, and services that the organization depends on are understood and communicated
clauses.rationale: PM-8/PM-11 mission/business dependencies; SA-9 external services; CP-2 contingency planning.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 emphasizes understanding dependencies from supply chain and partner services. SP 800-53 partially covers through contingency and supply chain controls.

clauses.title: Risk management objectives are established and expressed as statements that articulate the basis for cybersecurity risk management decisions
clauses.rationale: PM-9 risk management strategy; PM-28 risk framing; RA-1 risk assessment policy.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes explicit risk management objectives. SP 800-53 covers through risk strategy and framing.

clauses.title: Risk appetite and risk tolerance statements are established, communicated, and maintained
clauses.rationale: PM-9 risk management strategy includes risk tolerance; PM-28 risk framing.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 requires explicit risk appetite statements. SP 800-53 addresses risk tolerance within strategy.

clauses.title: Cybersecurity risk management activities and outcomes are included in enterprise risk management processes
clauses.rationale: PM-9 risk management strategy; PM-28 risk framing at enterprise level; PM-1 program integration.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 emphasizes ERM integration. SP 800-53 supports but the integration with non-security enterprise risk is less explicit.

clauses.title: Strategic direction that describes appropriate risk response options is established and communicated
clauses.rationale: PM-9 risk strategy; RA-3 risk response identification; CA-5 remediation planning.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 requires strategic risk response direction. SP 800-53 covers through risk management strategy and treatment.

clauses.title: Lines of communication across the organization are established for cybersecurity risks, including risks from suppliers and other third parties
clauses.rationale: PM-15 security contacts; PM-16 threat awareness; IR-6/IR-7 incident communication; SR-1 supply chain risk.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 emphasizes organizational risk communication pathways. SP 800-53 covers specific communication channels but systematic risk communication planning less explicit.

clauses.title: A standardized method for calculating, documenting, categorizing, and prioritizing cybersecurity risks is established and communicated
clauses.rationale: RA-1 risk assessment policy; RA-2 categorization; RA-3 risk assessment methodology; PM-9 risk strategy.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 requires standardized risk calculation methodology. SP 800-53 RA-3 covers comprehensive risk assessment.

clauses.title: Strategic opportunities (positive risks) are characterized and are included in organizational cybersecurity risk discussions
clauses.rationale: PM-9 risk management strategy may include opportunity considerations.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 explicitly addresses positive risks/opportunities. SP 800-53 is threat/vulnerability focused and doesn't address strategic opportunities.

clauses.title: Organizational leadership is responsible and accountable for cybersecurity risk and fosters a culture that is risk-aware, ethical, and continually improving
clauses.rationale: PM-1 program plan; PM-2 senior security role; PM-13 workforce; AT-2 awareness.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 emphasizes leadership accountability and culture. SP 800-53 addresses roles and awareness but organizational culture is less explicit.

clauses.title: Roles, responsibilities, and authorities related to cybersecurity risk management are established, communicated, understood, and enforced
clauses.rationale: PM-2 role assignment; PS-1/PS-2 personnel roles; PL-1 planning roles; PM-13 workforce.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes enforcement and understanding. SP 800-53 covers role assignment comprehensively.

clauses.title: Adequate resources are allocated commensurate with the cybersecurity risk strategy, roles and responsibilities, and policies
clauses.rationale: PM-3 information security resources; PM-13 workforce resources.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 ties resource allocation to risk strategy. PM-3 addresses resources but risk-proportional allocation less explicit.

clauses.title: Cybersecurity is included in human resources practices
clauses.rationale: PS family comprehensive for personnel security; AT family for training; PM-13 workforce development.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SP 800-53 PS/AT families well aligned with HR security practices.

clauses.title: A cybersecurity supply chain risk management program, strategy, objectives, policies, and processes are established and agreed to by organizational stakeholders
clauses.rationale: SR-1 supply chain risk management policy; SR-2 supply chain controls; SR-3 supply chain risk assessment; PM-30 supply chain risk management.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SP 800-53 Rev 5 SR family is well aligned with CSF supply chain governance.

clauses.title: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities for suppliers, customers, and partners are established and communicated
clauses.rationale: SA-4 acquisition requirements; SA-9 external services; SR-1/SR-3 supply chain roles and assessments.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 specifically addresses customer and partner roles. SP 800-53 focuses on supplier roles.

clauses.title: Cybersecurity supply chain risk management is integrated into cybersecurity and enterprise risk management, risk assessment, and improvement processes
clauses.rationale: SR-1/SR-2 supply chain integration; PM-9 risk strategy integration; PM-30 supply chain risk management plan.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes integration with broader enterprise risk. SP 800-53 addresses supply chain risk management but enterprise-wide integration is less explicit.

clauses.title: Supply chain risk management lifecycle (priorities, requirements, plans, assessments, actions, monitoring)
clauses.rationale: SR family comprehensively covers supply chain risk management lifecycle from assessment through monitoring.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 includes supply chain decommissioning and lifecycle management. SP 800-53 SR family covers most aspects.

clauses.title: Inventories of hardware managed by the organization are maintained
clauses.rationale: CM-8 directly covers hardware component inventory with automated discovery.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Inventories of software, services, and systems managed by the organization are maintained
clauses.rationale: CM-8 component inventory (includes software); PM-5 system inventory; CM-10 software usage.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Representations of the organization's authorized network communication and internal and external network data flows are maintained
clauses.rationale: AC-4 information flow enforcement; PL-8 security architecture; CA-3 information exchange; SC-7 boundary definition.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 requires maintained data flow representations. SP 800-53 addresses through architecture and flow controls but explicit data flow documentation less mandated.

clauses.title: Inventories of services provided by suppliers are maintained
clauses.rationale: SA-9 external services identification; SR-6 supplier assessments; PM-5 system inventory.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 requires specific supplier service inventory. SP 800-53 covers through external service controls but dedicated inventory less explicit.

clauses.title: Assets are prioritized based on classification, criticality, resources, and impact to the mission
clauses.rationale: RA-2 security categorization; PM-11 mission process definition; CP-2 contingency priority; PM-7 architecture priorities.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 combines multiple prioritization criteria. SP 800-53 covers through categorization and mission analysis.

clauses.title: Inventories of data and corresponding metadata for designated data types are maintained
clauses.rationale: RA-2 data categorization; CM-8 component inventory; SI-12 information management.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 specifically requires data inventories. SP 800-53 categorizes data but doesn't require explicit data inventory with metadata.

clauses.title: Systems, hardware, software, services, and data are managed throughout their life cycles
clauses.rationale: SA-3 SDLC; SA-22 unsupported components; CM-8 inventory lifecycle; SI-12 data lifecycle; MP-6 media sanitization.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 requires holistic lifecycle management. SP 800-53 covers through various lifecycle controls.

clauses.title: Vulnerabilities in assets are identified, validated, and recorded
clauses.rationale: RA-5 vulnerability identification and scanning; SI-2 flaw identification; SI-5 vulnerability advisories.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Cyber threat intelligence is received from information sharing forums and sources
clauses.rationale: PM-16 threat awareness program; SI-5 security alerts; PM-15 security contacts.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Internal and external threats to the organization are identified and recorded
clauses.rationale: RA-3 risk assessment includes threat identification; PM-16 threat awareness; RA-10 threat hunting.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Potential impacts and likelihoods of threats exploiting vulnerabilities are identified and recorded
clauses.rationale: RA-3 directly covers impact and likelihood assessment.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Threats, vulnerabilities, likelihoods, and impacts are used to understand inherent risk and inform risk response prioritization
clauses.rationale: RA-3 comprehensive risk assessment; PM-9 risk strategy; CA-5 risk response prioritization.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Risk responses are chosen, prioritized, planned, tracked, and communicated
clauses.rationale: RA-3 risk response; PM-9 strategy; CA-5 POA&M tracking; PM-4 plan of action tracking.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Changes and exceptions are managed, assessed for risk impact, and recorded
clauses.rationale: CM-3 change control; CM-4 impact analysis; CA-6 authorization; PM-9 risk management.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 specifically addresses exception management. SP 800-53 covers through change and authorization controls.

clauses.title: Processes for receiving, analyzing, and responding to vulnerability disclosures are established
clauses.rationale: RA-5 vulnerability management; SI-2 remediation; SI-5 advisories; PM-15 information sharing.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 specifically addresses vulnerability disclosure processes (VDP). SP 800-53 covers vulnerability management but formal VDP less explicit.

clauses.title: The authenticity and integrity of hardware and software are assessed prior to acquisition and use
clauses.rationale: SR-4 provenance; SR-5 authenticity; SR-9 tamper resistance; SR-10 inspection; SR-11 component authenticity; SA-4 acquisition requirements.
clauses.gaps: Minor: SP 800-53 SR family covers hardware/software integrity comprehensively.

clauses.title: Critical suppliers are assessed prior to acquisition
clauses.rationale: SR-3 supply chain assessment; SR-5 supply chain controls; SR-6 supplier assessments; SA-4 acquisition requirements.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes pre-acquisition supplier assessment. SP 800-53 covers through supply chain and acquisition controls.

clauses.title: Improvements are identified from evaluations
clauses.rationale: CA-2 assessment findings; CA-7 continuous monitoring improvements; PM-6 performance measures; PM-4 POA&M.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes systematic improvement identification. SP 800-53 generates findings but improvement process less formalized.

clauses.title: Improvements are identified from security tests and exercises, including those done in coordination with suppliers and relevant third parties
clauses.rationale: CA-8 penetration testing; IR-3 incident response testing; PM-14 testing/exercises; CP-4 contingency testing.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 includes third-party coordination in testing. SP 800-53 covers testing but supplier coordination less explicit.

clauses.title: Improvements are identified from execution of operational processes, procedures, and activities
clauses.rationale: CA-7 continuous monitoring; PM-6 measures; IR-4 incident analysis; SI-4 system monitoring.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 emphasizes operational improvement identification. SP 800-53 generates operational data but formalized improvement from operations is less explicit.

clauses.title: Incident response plans and other cybersecurity plans that affect operations are established, communicated, maintained, and improved based on lessons learned and other factors
clauses.rationale: IR-8 incident response plan; IR-3 testing/lessons learned; CP-2 contingency plan; CP-4 contingency testing.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Identities and credentials for authorized users, services, and hardware are managed by the organization
clauses.rationale: IA family comprehensive for identity and credential management.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials based on the context of interactions
clauses.rationale: IA-12 identity proofing; IA-4 identifier management; IA-5 authenticator management.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Users, services, and hardware are authenticated
clauses.rationale: IA-2 user authentication; IA-3 device authentication; IA-8 non-org users; IA-9 service identification.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Identity assertions are protected, conveyed, and verified
clauses.rationale: IA-2 authentication; IA-5 authenticator management; SC-23 session authenticity; IA-8 non-org users.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 addresses identity federation and assertion protocols. SP 800-53 covers through authentication controls.

clauses.title: Access permissions, entitlements, and authorizations are defined in a policy, managed, enforced, and reviewed, and incorporate the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
clauses.rationale: AC-2 account management; AC-3 access enforcement; AC-5 separation of duties; AC-6 least privilege; AC-24 access control decisions.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Physical access to assets is managed, monitored, and enforced commensurate with risk
clauses.rationale: PE-2 access authorizations; PE-3 access control; PE-6 monitoring; PE-8 access records.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Personnel are provided with awareness and training so that they possess the knowledge and skills to perform general tasks with cybersecurity risks in mind
clauses.rationale: AT-2 awareness training; AT-3 role-based training; PM-13 workforce.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Individuals in specialized roles are provided with awareness and training so that they possess the knowledge and skills to perform relevant tasks with cybersecurity risks in mind
clauses.rationale: AT-3 role-based training; PM-13 workforce development; IR-2 incident response training.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-at-rest is protected
clauses.rationale: SC-28 protection at rest; MP-4 media storage; MP-5 media transport; AC-3 access enforcement.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-in-transit is protected
clauses.rationale: SC-8 transmission protection; SC-12 key management; SC-13 cryptographic protection; AC-17 remote access.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-in-use is protected
clauses.rationale: SC-4 information in shared resources; AC-3/AC-4 access and flow control; SC-39 process isolation.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 explicitly addresses data-in-use protection (confidential computing, memory protection). SP 800-53 covers through general controls but data-in-use is less explicitly addressed.

clauses.title: Backups of data are created, protected, maintained, and tested in accordance with policy
clauses.rationale: CP-9 system backup; CP-6 alternate storage.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Configuration management practices are established and applied
clauses.rationale: CM family comprehensive for configuration management.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Software is maintained, replaced, and removed commensurate with risk
clauses.rationale: SI-2 flaw remediation; SA-22 unsupported components; CM-7 least functionality; CM-11 software installation.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Hardware is maintained, replaced, and removed commensurate with risk
clauses.rationale: MA-2 controlled maintenance; MA-6 timely maintenance; SA-22 unsupported components; CM-8 inventory.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 addresses hardware lifecycle management holistically. SP 800-53 covers through maintenance and inventory controls.

clauses.title: Log records are generated and made available for continuous monitoring
clauses.rationale: AU family comprehensive for log generation; CA-7 continuous monitoring.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Installation and execution of unauthorized software is prevented
clauses.rationale: CM-7(4)/(5) application allowlisting; CM-11 user-installed software.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Secure software development practices are integrated, and their performance is monitored throughout the software development life cycle
clauses.rationale: SA family comprehensive for secure development lifecycle.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Networks and environments are protected from unauthorized logical access and usage
clauses.rationale: SC-7 boundary protection; AC-4 information flow; AC-17 remote access; SC-32 partitioning.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: The organization's technology assets are protected from environmental threats
clauses.rationale: PE family comprehensive for environmental protection.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Mechanisms are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations
clauses.rationale: CP family contingency and resilience; SC-5 availability; SC-36 distributed processing.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Adequate resource capacity to ensure availability is maintained
clauses.rationale: AU-4 audit storage capacity; CP-2 capacity planning; SC-5 denial of service; PE-11 emergency power capacity.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 addresses general capacity management. SP 800-53 covers specific capacity contexts but general IT capacity management less explicit.

clauses.title: Networks and network services are monitored to find potentially adverse events
clauses.rationale: SI-4 system monitoring; SC-7 boundary monitoring; AU-6 audit review; CA-7 continuous monitoring.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: The physical environment is monitored to find potentially adverse events
clauses.rationale: PE-6 monitoring physical access; PE-3 physical access control; PE-20 asset monitoring.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Personnel activity and technology usage are monitored to find potentially adverse events
clauses.rationale: AU-6 audit review; AU-12 audit generation; SI-4 system monitoring; AC-2(4) automated account auditing.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: External service provider activities and services are monitored to find potentially adverse events
clauses.rationale: SA-9 external service monitoring; SR-6 supplier assessments; CA-7 continuous monitoring.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 specifically addresses external service monitoring. SP 800-53 covers through general monitoring and service controls.

clauses.title: Computing hardware and software, runtime environments, and their data are monitored to find potentially adverse events
clauses.rationale: SI-4 system monitoring; SI-7 software/firmware integrity; AU-6 audit review.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Potentially adverse events are analyzed to better understand associated activities
clauses.rationale: SI-4 system monitoring; AU-6 audit analysis; IR-4 incident handling/analysis.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Information is correlated from multiple sources
clauses.rationale: AU-6(5) integrated analysis; SI-4(16) correlating information; AU-6(3) correlate audit repositories.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Information on adverse events is provided to authorized staff and tools
clauses.rationale: SI-4(5) system alerts; IR-6 incident reporting; AU-6(1) automated process integration.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Cyber threat intelligence and other contextual information are integrated into the analysis
clauses.rationale: PM-16 threat awareness; RA-3 risk context; SI-5 advisories; RA-10 threat hunting.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes threat intelligence integration into analysis. SP 800-53 covers threat intelligence but analytical integration less explicit.

clauses.title: Incidents are declared when adverse events meet the defined incident criteria
clauses.rationale: IR-4 incident handling includes declaration; IR-5 incident monitoring; IR-6 reporting.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: The incident response plan is executed in coordination with relevant third parties once an incident is declared
clauses.rationale: IR-4 incident handling; IR-6 reporting; IR-7 assistance; IR-8 response plan.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Incident reports are triaged and validated
clauses.rationale: IR-4 incident handling includes triage; IR-5 incident monitoring.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Incidents are categorized and prioritized
clauses.rationale: IR-4 incident handling includes categorization; IR-5 monitoring for tracking.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes formal categorization and prioritization. SP 800-53 IR controls cover but with less categorization specificity.

clauses.title: Incidents are escalated or elevated as needed
clauses.rationale: IR-4 incident handling; IR-6 reporting (includes escalation); IR-7 assistance.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 specifically addresses escalation procedures. SP 800-53 covers through incident reporting.

clauses.title: The criteria for initiating incident recovery are applied
clauses.rationale: IR-4 incident handling includes recovery initiation; CP-10 system recovery.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 requires specific recovery initiation criteria. SP 800-53 covers recovery but formal criteria less explicit.

clauses.title: Analysis is performed to determine what has taken place during an incident and root cause
clauses.rationale: IR-4 incident analysis; AU-6 audit analysis; SI-4 monitoring data.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Actions performed during an investigation are recorded, and the records' integrity and provenance are preserved
clauses.rationale: IR-4 incident documentation; AU-9 protection of audit information; AU-11 audit retention.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes investigation record integrity and chain of custody. SP 800-53 covers audit protection but forensic record provenance less explicit.

clauses.title: Incident data and metadata are collected, and their integrity and provenance are preserved
clauses.rationale: IR-4 incident data collection; AU-3 audit content; AU-9 protection; AU-11 retention.
clauses.gaps: Minor: Same as RS.AN-06 - metadata and provenance focus is more specific in CSF 2.0.

clauses.title: An incident's magnitude is estimated and validated
clauses.rationale: IR-4 incident analysis; IR-5 monitoring; RA-3 impact assessment.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 specifically addresses magnitude estimation. SP 800-53 covers through incident analysis.

clauses.title: Internal and external stakeholders are notified of incidents
clauses.rationale: IR-6 incident reporting; IR-7 incident response assistance and coordination.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Information is shared with designated internal and external stakeholders
clauses.rationale: IR-6 reporting; PM-15 security contacts; PM-16 threat awareness sharing.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes structured incident information sharing. SP 800-53 covers reporting but information sharing mechanisms less detailed.

clauses.title: Incidents are contained
clauses.rationale: IR-4 incident handling includes containment; SC-7 boundary protection for isolation.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Incidents are eradicated
clauses.rationale: IR-4 incident handling includes eradication; SI-3 malware removal.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: The recovery portion of the incident response plan is executed once initiated from the incident response process
clauses.rationale: CP-10 system recovery; IR-4 incident recovery; CP-2 contingency plan execution.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Recovery actions are selected, scoped, and prioritized, considering the business impact of the incident
clauses.rationale: CP-10 recovery; CP-2 prioritized contingency plan; IR-4 incident-informed recovery.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes business impact consideration in recovery prioritization. SP 800-53 covers through contingency planning.

clauses.title: The integrity of backups and other restoration assets is verified before using them for restoration
clauses.rationale: CP-9 system backup; CP-9(1) testing for reliability/integrity.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 explicitly requires integrity verification before restoration. CP-9(1) covers backup testing.

clauses.title: Critical mission functions and cybersecurity risk management are considered to establish post-incident operational norms
clauses.rationale: CP-10 recovery; IR-4 post-incident; PM-11 mission process definition.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 addresses establishment of new operational norms post-incident. SP 800-53 covers recovery but post-incident norm establishment less explicit.

clauses.title: The integrity of restored assets is verified, systems and services are restored, and normal operating status is confirmed
clauses.rationale: CP-10 system recovery; SI-7 integrity verification; CA-7 continuous monitoring for confirmation.
clauses.gaps: Minor: CSF 2.0 emphasizes post-recovery integrity verification. SP 800-53 covers through recovery and integrity controls.

clauses.title: The end of incident recovery is declared based on criteria, and incident-related documentation is completed
clauses.rationale: IR-4 incident handling closure; IR-3 lessons learned documentation.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 requires formal recovery closure criteria. SP 800-53 covers incident closure but formal end-of-recovery criteria less explicit.

clauses.title: Recovery activities and progress in restoring operational capabilities are communicated to designated internal and external stakeholders
clauses.rationale: IR-6 incident reporting (includes recovery status); IR-7 assistance; CP-2 communication plan.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 emphasizes recovery-specific communication. SP 800-53 covers through incident reporting but recovery communication specifically is less detailed.

clauses.title: Public updates on incident recovery are shared using approved methods and messaging
clauses.rationale: IR-6 reporting; IR-7 assistance for external communication.
clauses.gaps: CSF 2.0 specifically addresses public communications. SP 800-53 covers incident reporting but public/media communications strategy less explicit.
